objinfo.numberleaves: 2The full sheet was folded to form two leaves, with Blake's letter written on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet, which was sealed. The second verso is not photographed.

provenance.name: Cumberland Papers
provenance.note: George Cumberland; bequeathed to his son, George Cumberland; presented to the British Library in 1849, as part of the Cumberland Papers consisting of thirty-one volumes and two rolls, on condition that these should not be opened until 1900.

desc.objtitle: I ought long ago to have written, Object 1

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves, with Blake's letter written on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet, which was sealed. The second verso is not photographed.
In the top right corner the British Library folio number "330" is inscribed in an unknown hand.

lg.l: Dear Cumberland
I ought long ago to have written to you to thank
you for your kind recommendation to DrDr TruslerJohn Trusler which

thothough it has faild failed of Success is not the less to be rememberd remembered
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1528), Erdman (page 703), and Keynes (*Letters*, page 10) read "Success" as "success".
by me with Gratitude.
I have made him a Drawing in my best manner
he has sent it back with a Letter full of Criticisms inBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1528) omits "has" from his transcription.
which he says It accords not with his Intentions whichErdman (page 703) reads "It" as "it".
areare to Reject all Fancy from his Work. How far hePart of the "a" in "are" is obscured by the remnant of the wafer seal.
Expects to please I cannot tell. But as I cannot paint

DirtyDirty rags & old Shoes where I ought to place NakNakeddd BeautyPart of the "D" in "Dirty" is obscured by the remnant of the wafer seal. Keynes (*Letters*, page 10) reads "Shoes" as "shoes". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1528), Erdman (page 703), and Keynes (page 10) read "Nakdd" as "Naked".
or Simple ornament. I despair of Ever pleasing one ClassErdman (page 703) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 10) read "Simple" as "simple".
of Men. Unfortunately our authors of books are among
this Class how soon we Shall have a change for the better
I cannot Prophecy. DrDr TruslerJohn Trusler says "Your Fancy fromfrom
What I have seen of it. & I have seen variety at MrMr Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1528), Erdman (page 704), and Keynes (*Letters*, page 10) read “What” as “what”.
CumberlandsCumberland's seems to be in the other world or the World of
Spirits. which accords not with my Intentions. which whilst
living in This World Wish to follow the Nature of it"
I could not help Smiling at the difference between the doctrines
of DrDr TruslerJohn Trusler & those of Christ. But however for his

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves, with Blake's letter written on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet, which was sealed. The second verso is not photographed.

lg.l: own sake I am sorry that a Man should be so enamourd enamored enamoured
of RowlandsonsRowlandson's caricatures as to call them copies from life &
manners or fit Things for a Clergyman to write upon
Pray let me intreatentreat you to persevere in your DesigningDesigning Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1529) reads “Designing” as “Disigning”.
it is the only source of Pleasure all your other pleasures dependBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1529) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 11) read "all" as "All".
upon It. It is the Tree your Pleasures are the Fruit. YourKeynes (*Letters*, page 11) reads "upon It" as "upon it". Erdman (page 704) reads "your Pleasures" as "Your Pleasures".
Inventions of Intellectual Visions are the Stamina of everyeverything
thingeverything you value. Go on if not for your own sake yet for
ours who love & admire your works. but above all For
the Sake of the Arts. Do not throw aside for any long time

the honourhonor intended you by Nature to revive the Greek workworkmanshipBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1529) Erdman (page 704), and Keynes (*Letters*, page 11) read the word fragments split between lines 22 and 23, “work / manship”, as a single word, “workmanship”.
manshipworkmanship. I study your outlines as usual just as if they
were antiques.
As to Myself about whom you are so kindly
Interested. I live by Miracle. I am Painting small

Pictures from the Bible. For as to Engraving in which artBlake's "small / Pictures from the Bible" refers to his Biblical temperas, available through the Index of Works as Paintings Illustrating the Bible.
I cannot reproach mymyselfself with any neglect yet I am
laid by in a corner as if I did not Exist & Since
my YoungsYoung'sEdward Young Night Thoughts have been publishd published Even
JohnsonJoseph Johnson & FuseliHenry Fuseli have discarded my Graver. But
as I know that He who Works & has his health cannot

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves, with Blake's letter written on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet, which was sealed. The second verso is not photographed.
In the top right corner the British Library folio number "331" is inscribed in an unknown hand.

lg.l: starve. I laugh at FortFortuneune & Go on & on. I think Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1529), Erdman (page 704), and Keynes (*Letters*, page 11) read "Fortune" for the unclear word ending.
I foresee better Things than I have ever seen. My Work
pleases my employer & I have an order for Fifty small
Pictures at One Guinea each which is Something betterKeynes (*Letters*, page 11) reads "One" as "one". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1529n7) lists some of these "small / Pictures".
than mere copying after another artist. But above all
I feel myself happy & contented let what will come
having passed now near twenty years in ups & downs
I am used to them & perhaps a little practisepractice in them
may turn out to benefit. It is now Exactly Twenty
years since I was upon the ocean of business & ThoThough I
laugh at Fortune I am perswaded persauded that She Alone is
the Governor of Worldy Riches. & when it is Fit She
will call on me till then I wait with Patience in hopes
that She is busied among my Friends.
With Mine & My WifesWife's best compliments to
MrsMrs CumberlandI remainBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1530) and Erdman (page 704) read "Mrs" as "Mrs".
Yours SincerelyErdman (page 704) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 11) read "Sincerely" as "sincerely".
Hercules Buildings
Lambeth
AugstAugust 26. 1799
